display_asset.caption: The space shuttle Challenger exploded shortly after lifting off.

summaries.body: The explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, 30 years ago today, remains one of the worst accidents of the American space program.

display_asset.caption: Ethan Couch, known as the “affluenza teen” after he killed four people in a drunken-driving crash in 2013, left Mexico City headed for Texas on Thursday.

summaries.body: Ethan Couch, the teenager whose lawyers cited "affluenza" after he killed four people in a drunken-driving crash, returned to Texas from Mexico, where he had fled.

display_asset.caption: The headquarters of Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt. For the fourth quarter, the bank reported a net loss of 2.1 billion euros, compared with a net profit of 441 million euros a year earlier.

summaries.body: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, confirmed that it had a record loss of 6.8 billion euros, or $7.4 billion in 2015, the toll of legal problems and management turmoil.

display_asset.caption: Cars on a residential street in Washington on Saturday, after the city was hit by a snowstorm.

summaries.body: Washington imposed $1.3 million in parking fines during the snowstorm. People who did not move their cars from snow emergency routes were fined $250, more if towed.
Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, a comedian whose anti-Semitic comments stirred debate in France, said he was detained at Hong Kong's airport and barred from the territory.

display_asset.caption: Novak Djokovic, the No. 1 seed at the Australian Open, chasing down a shot on Thursday in a 6-1, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3 victory over Roger Federer in the semifinals.

summaries.body: Novak Djokovic, the world's No. 1 player, beat Roger Federer, 6-1, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, to reach the Australian Open men's final.

display_asset.credit: Photo by John Nordell/The Christian Science Monitor

summaries.body: Statewide exams given to third- through eighth-grade students in New York will no longer be timed, ending the call of “pencils down.”
Despite what people often believe, the strength of a state's recovery from the economic recession has little to do with whether it is red or blue, a columnist writes.

display_asset.caption: Carrie Brownstein, left, and Gaby Hoffmann in “Transparent.”

summaries.body: Shows like "Transparent" on TV right now allow women "to feel anything and everything," a sharp contrast from how they exist in the '50s-era film "Carol."

display_asset.caption: On certain subway lines, New York may adopt trains with open gangways to allow passengers to move freely between cars.

summaries.body: A new generation of subway trains with open pathways between cars could arrive in New York City as early as 2020, and would create a greater capacity for riders.

display_asset.caption: Cate Blanchett and Richard Roxburgh in the Sydney Theater Company’s “Uncle Vanya” in 2012.

summaries.body: Cate Blanchett will make her Broadway debut next season in "The Present," an adaptation of a Chekhov play directed by John Crowley.

display_asset.caption: The actor Joseph Fiennes will play Michael Jackson in a comedy for British television.

summaries.body: Joseph Fiennes, a white British actor, will play Michael Jackson in a British television comedy. There has been negative reaction on social media.

display_asset.caption: The sale gives Visual China Group ownership of iconic photographs. This image from the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989 is owned by Reuters and licensed by Corbis.

summaries.body: The sale of the Corbis photography archive has given a Chinese media company control over images from the 1989 crackdown in Tiananmen Square.
A federal judge has dismissed an attempt to halt the removal of prominent Confederate monuments in New Orleans.

display_asset.caption: Priscilla Kelly Delmaro appeared in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday before she was released from custody.
display_asset.credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times

summaries.body: Priscilla Kelly Delmaro, a psychic, was released after serving eight months in jail for bilking a man out of more than $550,000.

display_asset.caption: Hillary Clinton at the Steyer Opera House in Decorah, Iowa, on Tuesday.

summaries.body: When asked at a campaign event in Iowa whether she would consider nominating President Obama for the Supreme Court, Hillary Clinton said, "That's a great idea."

display_asset.caption: Thornton Dial at his studio in Bessemer, Ala., in 2011.
display_asset.credit: Josh Anderson for The New York Times

summaries.body: Thornton Dial, a self-taught artist whose work told the story of black struggle in the South, died on Monday in Alabama. He was 87.

display_asset.caption: Nate Parker’s film, “The Birth of a Nation,” is based on the true story of Nat Turner, who in 1831 led a slave rebellion, which brought severe retaliation in return.

summaries.body: Fox Searchlight bid a Sundance record $17.5 million for “The Birth of a Nation,” a slave-revolt drama written and directed by Nate Parker, who also plays the lead character.
A journalist for the University of Michigan newspaper tried out for the football team, which went about as well as you might expect.

display_asset.caption: Rose made her debut on Thursday in the role of the pet rat Toby in the Broadway play “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time.”

summaries.body: A freak accident did what a roadside dumping and poison could not do: kill Rose, a rat with a role in “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time" on Broadway.

display_asset.caption: The Joker from Batman: Arkham City.

summaries.body: The video game industry's demand for strong character voices is offering actors a new route to fame, and many are building fan bases.
For one day next month, Brazil will deploy 220,000 troops to spread awareness about Zika as an official said it was “badly losing the battle” against the disease.

display_asset.caption: Ivory obtained through elephant poaching was destroyed in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday.

summaries.body: Sri Lanka crushed 1.5 tons of ivory, making it the first South Asian nation to publicly destroy ivory obtained through elephant poaching.

display_asset.caption: Frida Kahlo’s “Dos Mujeres (Salvadora y Herminia),” from 1928.

summaries.body: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has acquired its first painting by Frida Kahlo. The 1928 work depicts two Mexican women set against dense tropical foliage.

display_asset.caption: Bobby Ray Simmons Jr., better known as B.o.B.

summaries.body: The rapper B.o.B, insisting that the earth is flat, released a “diss track” aimed at the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson after the two argued on Twitter.
If your U.S. passport is expiring this year, you should renew it now. State Department officials expect a flood of renewals of 10-year passports issued in 2006 and 2007.

display_asset.caption: Apartments sit on the edge of an eroding coastal bluff in Pacifica, Calif.

summaries.body: Apartments atop a cliff near San Francisco are dangerously close to falling into the Pacific Ocean after powerful waves and heavy rains accelerated the erosion of bluffs.
"The Tale of Kitty-In-Boots," a previously unpublished story by the author Beatrix Potter, features an older version of Peter Rabbit.
Ten police officers in Afghanistan were poisoned by a rogue officer and then shot in the head by Taliban fighters the officer was working with, an official said.

display_asset.caption: When Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller, took office in early 2014, he said it was apparent then that aspects of the retirement system were “hanging by a thread.”

summaries.body: New York City’s pension system is vulnerable to an “operational failure,” according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.
